eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
description: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
- Short shaking can be used to give impact (explosion, hit)
- Shaking can go indefinitely to set an ambiance (engine vibration, earthquake, pulsing)
- Low frequency shaking allows to simulate slow moving objects (ship rocking back and forth)
Release notes:
- Version 3.0.0
- No adaptation of the game events is needed.
- It fixes an issue when used with scrolling, the amplitude will feel bigger in this case.
- The shaking relies on noise which could feel a bit different.
- This extension can no longer do impulses. For this, another extension "Camera impulse" can be used.

events.comment: Use user defined default values when there is no layer specific value set.

Shake the layer camera.
Save the camera displacement to revert it in onScenePostEvents.

variables.description: Shake the camera on layers chosen with configuration actions.
variables.name: ShakeCamera
variables.sentence: Shake camera for _PARAM1_ seconds with _PARAM2_ seconds of easing to start and _PARAM3_ seconds to stop

variables.description: Shake the camera on the specified layer, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, zoom). This action is deprecated. Please use the other one with the same name.
variables.name: CameraShake
variables.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

events.comment: Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeY

variables.description: Start shaking the camera indefinitely.
variables.name: StartShaking
variables.sentence: Start shaking the camera with _PARAM1_ seconds of easing

variables.description: Stop shaking the camera.
variables.name: StopShaking
variables.sentence: Stop shaking the camera with _PARAM1_ seconds of easing

variables.description: Mark a layer as shakable.
variables.name: SetLayerShakable
variables.sentence: Mark the layer: _PARAM2_ as shakable: _PARAM1_

variables.description: Check if the camera is shaking.
variables.name: IsShaking
variables.sentence: Camera is shaking

variables.description: Change the translation amplitude of the shaking (in pixels).
variables.name: SetLayerTranslationAmplitude
variables.sentence: Change the translation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_; _PARAM2_ (layer: _PARAM3_)

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeY

variables.description: Change the rotation amplitude of the shaking (in degrees).
variables.name: SetLayerRotationAmplitude
variables.sentence: Change the rotation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_ degrees (layer: _PARAM2_)

variables.description: Change the zoom factor amplitude of the shaking. The shaking will zoom and unzoom by this factor (for instance 1.0625 is a valid value).
variables.name: SetLayerZoomAmplitude
variables.sentence: Change the zoom factor amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_ (layer: _PARAM2_)

variables.description: Change the number of back and forth per seconds.
variables.name: SetLayerShakingFrequency
variables.sentence: Change the shaking frequency to _PARAM1_ (layer: _PARAM2_)

variables.description: Change the default translation amplitude of the shaking (in pixels).
variables.name: SetDefaultTranslationAmplitude
variables.sentence: Change the default translation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_; _PARAM2_

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (in pixels)
parameters.name: AmplitudeY

variables.description: Change the default rotation amplitude of the shaking (in degrees).
variables.name: SetDefaultRotationAmplitude
variables.sentence: Change the default rotation amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_ degrees

variables.description: Change the default zoom factor amplitude of the shaking. The shaking will zoom and unzoom by this factor (for instance 1.0625 is a valid value).

variables.sentence: Change the default zoom factor amplitude of the shaking to _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the default number of back and forth per seconds.

inlineCode: * Create the manager of noise generators.
* Create a noise generator with a seed.
// Make the circle perimeter equals to the looping period
// to keep the same perceived frequency with or without looping.
noiseSum += noiseFunction(x * frequency, y * frequency, z * frequency, w * frequency) * amplitude;
A fast javascript implementation of simplex noise by Jonas Wagner
Based on a speed-improved simplex noise algorithm for 2D, 3D and 4D in Java.
Which is based on example code by Stefan Gustavson (stegu@itn.liu.se).
Better rank ordering method by Stefan Gustavson in 2012.
Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy
of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal
in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights
to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell
copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is
furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:
The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all
copies or substantial portions of the Software.

LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM,
OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN THE
/** Deterministic simplex noise generator suitable for 2D, 3D and 4D spaces. */
* This involves some setup. You can save a few cpu cycles by reusing the same instance.
* @param {(() => number)|string|number} randomOrSeed A random number generator or a seed (string|number).
const random = typeof randomOrSeed == 'function' ? randomOrSeed : alea(randomOrSeed);
* Samples the noise field in 2 dimensions
let n0 = 0; // Noise contributions from the three corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y) * F2; // Hairy factor for 2D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y distances from the cell origin
// For the 2D case, the simplex shape is an equilateral triangle.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1; // Offsets for second (middle) corner of simplex in (i,j) coords
// A step of (1,0) in (i,j) means a step of (1-c,-c) in (x,y), and
// a step of (0,1) in (i,j) means a step of (-c,1-c) in (x,y), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G2; // Offsets for middle corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
const x2 = x0 - 1.0 + 2.0 * G2; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the three simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the three corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0); // (x,y) of grad3 used for 2D gradient
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1);
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to return values in the interval [-1,1].
* Samples the noise field in 3 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3; // Noise contributions from the four corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y + z) * F3; // Very nice and simple skew factor for 3D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z distances from the cell origin
// For the 3D case, the simplex shape is a slightly irregular tetrahedron.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1, k1; // Offsets for second corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
let i2, j2, k2; // Offsets for third corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
// A step of (1,0,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (1-c,-c,-c) in (x,y,z),
// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G3; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x3 = x0 - 1.0 + 3.0 * G3; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the four simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the four corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad3[gi0 + 2] * z0);
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1]]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad3[gi1 + 2] * z1);
const gi2 = permMod12[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2]]] * 3;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad3[gi2 + 2] * z2);
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad3[gi3] * x3 + grad3[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad3[gi3 + 2] * z3);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to stay just inside [-1,1]
* Samples the noise field in 4 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3, n4; // Noise contributions from the five corners
// Skew the (x,y,z,w) space to determine which cell of 24 simplices we're in
const s = (x + y + z + w) * F4; // Factor for 4D skewing
const t = (i + j + k + l) * G4; // Factor for 4D unskewing
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z,w) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z,w distances from the cell origin
// For the 4D case, the simplex is a 4D shape I won't even try to describe.
// To find out which of the 24 possible simplices we're in, we need to
// determine the magnitude ordering of x0, y0, z0 and w0.
// Six pair-wise comparisons are performed between each possible pair
// of the four coordinates, and the results are used to rank the numbers.
// simplex[c] is a 4-vector with the numbers 0, 1, 2 and 3 in some order.
// Many values of c will never occur, since e.g. x>y>z>w makes x<z, y<w and x<w
// impossible. Only the 24 indices which have non-zero entries make any sense.
// We use a thresholding to set the coordinates in turn from the largest magnitude.
// Rank 2 denotes the second largest coordinate.
// Rank 1 denotes the second smallest coordinate.
// The integer offsets for the second simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the third simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the fourth simplex corner
// The fifth corner has all coordinate offsets = 1, so no need to compute that.
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G4; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G4; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x3 = x0 - i3 + 3.0 * G4; // Offsets for fourth corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x4 = x0 - 1.0 + 4.0 * G4; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the five simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the five corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad4[gi0] * x0 + grad4[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad4[gi0 + 2] * z0 + grad4[gi0 + 3] * w0);
const gi1 = (perm[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1 + perm[ll + l1]]]] % 32) * 4;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]
* This is exported only for (internal) testing purposes.
* Do not rely on this export.
The ALEA PRNG and masher code used by simplex-noise.js
is based on code by Johannes Baagøe, modified by Jonas Wagner.
See alea.md for the full license.

variables.description: Generate a number from 2 dimensional simplex noise.
variables.name: Noise2d

variables.description: Generate a number from 3 dimensional simplex noise.
variables.name: Noise3d

variables.description: Generate a number from 4 dimensional simplex noise.
variables.name: Noise4d

variables.description: Create a noise generator with default settings (frequency = 1,  octaves = 1, persistence = 0.5, lacunarity = 2).
variables.name: Create
variables.sentence: Create a noise generator named _PARAM1_

variables.description: Delete a noise generator and loose its settings.
variables.name: Delete
variables.sentence: Delete _PARAM1_ noise generator

variables.description: Delete all noise generators and loose their settings.
variables.name: DeleteAll
variables.sentence: Delete all noise generators

variables.description: The seed is a number used to generate the random noise. Setting the same seed will result in the same random noise generation. It's for example useful to generate the same world, by saving this seed value and reusing it later to generate again a world.
variables.name: SetSeed
variables.sentence: Change the noise seed to _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the looping period on X used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on X.
variables.name: SetLoopPeriodX
variables.sentence: Change the looping period on X of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the looping period on Y used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on Y.
variables.name: SetLoopPeriodY
variables.sentence: Change the looping period on Y of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the base frequency used for noise generation. A lower frequency will zoom in the noise.
variables.name: SetFrequency
variables.sentence: Change the noise frequency of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the number of octaves used for noise generation. It can be seen as layers of noise with different zoom.
variables.name: SetOctaves
variables.sentence: Change the number of noise octaves of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the persistence used for noise generation. At its default value "0.5", it halves the noise amplitude at each octave.
variables.name: SetPersistence
variables.sentence: Change the noise persistence of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

variables.description: Change the lacunarity used for noise generation. At its default value "2", it doubles the frequency at each octave.
variables.name: SetLacunarity
variables.sentence: Change the noise lacunarity of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

variables.description: The seed used for noise generation.
variables.name: Seed

variables.description: The base frequency used for noise generation.
variables.name: Frequency

variables.description: The number of octaves used for noise generation.
variables.name: Octaves

variables.description: The persistence used for noise generation.
variables.name: Persistence

variables.description: The lacunarity used for noise generation.
variables.name: Lacunarity

objects.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
objects.name: ShakeObject
description: Shake an object (position, angle or scale).
It can be used for:
- Hit or impact
- Object slowly rocking back and forth (like a ship)
- Simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
The top-down RPG example uses this extension for damage animations ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://top-down-rpg)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle).
This behavior can be used on any type of object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle). Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters.
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake object _PARAM0_ for _PARAM2_ seconds. Modify position amplitude _PARAM3_ on X axis and _PARAM4_ on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM5_.  Wait _PARAM6_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM7_

events.comment: Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake

parameters.description: Amplitude of postion shake in X direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of position shake in Y direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.longDescription: Use a negative number to make the single-shake move in the opposite direction.
parameters.name: PowerY

parameters.description: Amplitude of angle rotation shake (in degrees)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerAngle

parameters.description: Amount of time between shakes (in seconds) (Default: 0.08)
parameters.longDescription: For a single-shake effect, set it to the same value as "Duration".
parameters.name: TimeBetweenShakes

events.comment: Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached (or if the stop shaking function was called)

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake

animations.description: Stop any shaking of object that was initiated by the Shake Object extension.
animations.name: StopShaking

animations.description: Check if an object is shaking.
animations.fullName: Check if an object is shaking
animations.name: IsShaking

objects.description:
Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, scale)
This behavior can only be used on sprite objects.
objects.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngleScale

Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate object scale displacement, with linear decay over time

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading and overheating.
description: This extension allows objects to fire bullets.
It handles:
- Cooldown between shots
- Firing multiple bullets at a time ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fire-bullet))
- Ammo management
- Overheat
It can be used for:
- Twin-stick shooters ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://conviction-of-gun-dude-desktop))
- Shoot'em up ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://space-shooter))
A simple example shows how to make firing patterns ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://firing-patterns)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: FireBullet

events.comment: Creators can use the "FireBullet" action multiple times in a frame and it will be counted as a single "shot".
Subtract 1 from ammo (if not unlimited ammo)
Only reload the amount of ammo available

events.name: Reduce heat level (based on cooling rate)

externalEvents.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
externalEvents.name: EllipseMovement
externalEvents.shortDescription: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
description: It allows objects to move:
- on an ellipsis or arcs
- smoothly vertically or horizontally (by setting one radius to 0)
- on a sine wave (by adding a force)
It can be used for:
- Making objects float, such as powerups or coins
- Moving platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
- Making a player constantly turn right or left ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://star-seeker))

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: EllipseMovement

events.comment: Evaluate the center of movement from the object position and properties.
Update the center when the object is moved outside of the behavior.
Place the object according to the movement angle.
Save the position to detect when the object is moved outside of the behavior.
Update the movement angle for the next frame.

externalEvents.name: BoidsMovement
description: Simulates swarms or flocks movement following the separation, alignment, cohesion principles. The flock can be attracted to a location or avoid some obstacles.
The [Fish School example](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fish-school) shows how properties impact on the movement.

eventsFunctions.description: Define JavaScript classes.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineJavaScript

inlineCode: * @param {float} x - coordinate of the vectors starting position
* @param {float} y - coordinate of the vectors starting position
* Adds a velocity to this vector
* @param {Vector} referenceVector gets the velocity to be added
* Subtracts vectors verticies from a reference vector
* Methods for Separation, Cohesion, Alignment added
* Inspired from The Nature of Code - Daniel Shiffman
* @param {Vector} vector the vector to return the result
* Applys the three rules of boids
* Apply the acceleration from the steer force.
* Calculates and applies steering force towards a direction
* Alignment: calculate the average velocity for every nearby boid in the system
* Cohesion: calculate direction vector towards the average location of all nearby boids
// A vector pointing from the position to the target
* Add a boid to the R-Tree.
* Remove a boid from the R-Tree.
* Returns all the boids around the specified boid.
* @return {Boid[]} An array with all boids near the object.
// TODO The R-Tree should not allocate an array.
// Cap the number of boids between 20 and 40.
for (let i = 0; i < nearbys.length; i += step) {

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move as part of a flock.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: BoidsMovement

events.comment: Initiate and attach properties as objects variables

eventsFunctions.description: Intend to move in a given direction.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveInDirection
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM0_ intent to move in the direction _PARAM2_; _PARAM3_ (decision weight: _PARAM4_)

eventsFunctions.name: MoveToPosition

eventsFunctions.description: Intend to move toward an object.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveToObject

eventsFunctions.description: Intend to avoid an area with a given center and radius.
eventsFunctions.name: AvoidPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM0_ intend to avoid a radius of _PARAM4_ around _PARAM2_; _PARAM3_ (decision weight: _PARAM5_)

events.comment:
Evaluate at which distance the object will go past a location if it were to continue in its current direction.

speedUnitX = velocityX / speed
speedUnitY = velocityY / speed

deltaX = centerX - object.CenterX
deltaY = centerY - object.CenterY

normalX = -deltaY;
normalY = deltaX;

trajectoryDistance = speedUnitX * normalX + speedUnitY * normalY
If this distance is smaller than the specified radius, the Boid must try turn in the right direction to avoid the area.

eventsFunctions.description: Intend to avoid an area from an object center and a given radius.
eventsFunctions.name: AvoidObject
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM0_ intend to avoid a radius of _PARAM3_ around _PARAM2_  (decision weight: _PARAM4_)

events.comment: This allows to detect a change of "intial value" on hot reload.
Pass the configuration to the behavior (MaxValue must be set before Value).

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- background is resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the bar size is refreshed according to the value

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.
